subject: Re: [junit] How do i check if i am getting right output
msgSnippet: ... Au contraire. Java s right. C s wrong. In Java you know a n is a linefeed. No if s, and s, or but s. This means when you re writing or reading a protocol
messageBody:
Chris Dollin wrote:

> It's always puzzled me why Java got this wrong (yes, I think "wrong"
> is the appropriate term) when even C got it right. It means, for
> example, that various strings cannot be constants.

Au contraire. Java's right. C's wrong. In Java you know a \n is a
linefeed. No if's, and's, or but's. This means when you're writing or
reading a protocol or network file format that specifies a linefeed, you
know what you're getting. You can depend on it. In 2005 there is no good
reason to change the line separator to match some imagined platform
default. All reasonable text editors can handle \r, \n, or \r\n. Many
protocols and file formats specify one or the other of these. For
instance HTTP headers MUST be terminated with \r\n. \n and \r alone are
incorrect (though many clients are liberal in what they accept). This is
regardless of platform or OS.

We live in a multiplatform, multi-OS, multilingual world. Platform
defaults of all kinds are harmful. Data must not be tied to one type of
computer or operating system. We need multiplatform, multilingual,
multilocale data.


--
